children.text: We are given two Java programs to be executed in sequence. The first program (atcoder_ARC062_B) reads a string and computes a score. The second program (codeforces_58_B) reads an integer and then prints a sequence of integers.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: However, note the requirement: the entire sequence should be translated into a single Fortran program.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The first block (which is the first Java program) should read the input, and the last block (the second Java program) should produce the output. But note that the output of the first program is an integer (the score) and the second program expects an integer (n) from the input. So the integer output from the first program becomes the input to the second program. But wait: the first program reads a string and the second reads an integer. How do we chain them? The input to the entire sequence is the string for the first program.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The first program computes an integer (score). Then the second program uses that integer as its input (n). The output of the second program is the sequence of numbers.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: However, note that the second program does not read from the standard input until the first program has finished.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text:
Therefore, in the combined Fortran program:

1. We read the string (from standard input) for the first part. 2.

The second part then produces the output (which is a sequence of integers) to standard output. But note: the second program prints the integer n and then, in decreasing order from n-1 down to 1, prints every divisor of the current m (which starts as n) that is also a divisor of the next m (which is set to the divisor just found). So the plan for the Fortran program:

children.text: In Fortran, read(*,*) S will read one token (without spaces) and assign it to S, and then we use len_trim(S) to get the length. Let's code accordingly. We'll write the entire Fortran program. Note: We must declare the variables.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Alternatively, we can read the entire line and then use the first token? But the problem says the input is a string of 'g' and 'p'. And the Java program reads one token. We'll set:

      character(10000) :: S   ! to be safe.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Code:

      program combined
          implicit none
          character(10000) :: S
          integer :: score, i, n, m, length
          character :: my, his

          ! Read the input string (one token)
          read(*, *) S

          ! Get the length of the token (without trailing spaces)
          length = len_trim(S)

          score = 0
          do i = 1, length
              if (mod(i-1, 2) == 0) then
                  my = 'g'
              else
                  my = 'p'
              end if

              his = S(i:i)

              if (my /= his) then
                  if (my == 'p') then
                      score = score + 1
                  else
                      score = score - 1
                  end if
              end if
          end do

          n = score

          ! Now output n and then the divisors sequence
          write(*, '(I0, " ")') n

          m = n
          ! If n <= 1, the loop runs from n-1 down to 1: which may be negative, so we skip. do i = n-1, 1, -1
              if (mod(m, i) == 0) then
                  write(*, '(I0, " ")') i
                  m = i
              end if
          end do

      end program combined

  However, note: the second program in Java uses integer division? mod(m, i) is the modulus. In Fortran, mod(m, i) is the same. But what if i is 0? In the loop, i starts at n-1 and goes down to 1, so i>=1 -> no division by zero. Therefore, we are done. But note: the second program in Java does:

        System.out.println(i + " ");

      which is a newline after each divisor. Our Fortran write statement:

          write(*, '(I0, " ")') i

      also writes a newline? Because each write statement (without advance='no') writes a newline at the end? Yes. So the output format is: [n] [space] [newline]
        [i1] [space] [newline] [i2] [space] [newline]
        ...

          i=0: my='g', his='g' -> no change -> score=0. What if we input "p"?
          i=0: my='g', his='p' -> my ! = his -> and my='g' -> so score = -1. Then the second part: n=-1 -> output "-1 " and then the loop: i from -2 down to 1? -> no iteration. This is correct. However, the problem says the entire sequence.

However, note the requirement: the entire sequence should be translated into a single Fortran program. The first block (which is the first Java program) should read the input, and the last block (the second Java program) should produce the output. But note that the output of the first program is an integer (the score) and the second program expects an integer (n) from the input. So the integer output from the first program becomes the input to the second program.

But wait: the first program reads a string and the second reads an integer. How do we chain them?

The input to the entire sequence is the string for the first program. The first program computes an integer (score). Then the second program uses that integer as its input (n). The output of the second program is the sequence of numbers.

However, note that the second program does not read from the standard input until the first program has finished. Therefore, in the combined Fortran program:

1. We read the string (from standard input) for the first part.
2. Compute the score (without any I/O in between).
3. Then use that computed score as the integer 'n' for the second part.
4. The second part then produces the output (which is a sequence of integers) to standard output.

But note: the second program prints the integer n and then, in decreasing order from n-1 down to 1, prints every divisor of the current m (which starts as n) that is also a divisor of the next m (which is set to the divisor just found).

          length = len_trim(S)

          score = 0

              if (mod(i-1, 2) == 0) then   ! because in Java: index 0 is even -> i=1 in Fortran is the first character -> index0=0
                  my = 'g'
              else
                  my = 'p'
              end if

              his = S(i:i)

              if (my /= his) then
                  if (my == 'p') then
                      score = score + 1
                  else
                      score = score - 1

              end if

          ! Now set n = score

  Therefore, the Fortran code:

      We assume the string is read as a token (without spaces). We use read(*,*) S.

  However, what if the string has spaces? The first Java program uses next() which reads one token. So we must read one token. In Fortran, read(*,*) S will read one token (without spaces) and assign it to S, and then we use len_trim(S) to get the length.

  Let's code accordingly.

  We'll write the entire Fortran program.

  Note: We must declare the variables.

  We assume the string can be up to 10000 characters? But the problem doesn't specify. We can set a large maximum.

  Alternatively, we can read the entire line and then use the first token? But the problem says the input is a string of 'g' and 'p'. And the Java program reads one token.

  We'll set:

      character(10000) :: S   ! to be safe.

  Code:

      program combined
          implicit none
          character(10000) :: S
          integer :: score, i, n, m, length
          character :: my, his

          ! Read the input string (one token)
          read(*, *) S

          ! Get the length of the token (without trailing spaces)
          length = len_trim(S)

          score = 0
          do i = 1, length
              if (mod(i-1, 2) == 0) then
                  my = 'g'
              else
                  my = 'p'
              end if

              his = S(i:i)

              if (my /= his) then
                  if (my == 'p') then
                      score = score + 1
                  else
                      score = score - 1
                  end if
              end if
          end do

          n = score

          ! Now output n and then the divisors sequence
          write(*, '(I0, " ")') n

          m = n
          ! If n <= 1, the loop runs from n-1 down to 1: which may be negative, so we skip.
          do i = n-1, 1, -1
              if (mod(m, i) == 0) then
                  write(*, '(I0, " ")') i
                  m = i
              end if
          end do

      end program combined

        [i1] [space] [newline]
        [i2] [space] [newline]
        ...
